text: The name of the Latin-script letter D.

defs.etymology: From Latin dē.

text: of; ’s; used after the thing owned and before the owner
from (with the source or provenance of or at)
from (with the origin, starting point or initial reference of or at)
of (indicates the subject or cause of the adjective)
from (with the separation, exclusion or differentiation of)
Used to construct compound nouns (with attributive nouns).
(followed by the infinitive) Indicates a conditional desire.
Indicates a time of day or period of someone's life.
(after a noun and before a verb) Indicates the purpose of an object.
examples: Constitución española de 1812Spanish constitution of 1812
Spanish constitution of 1812
la cola del perrothe dog’s tail
the dog’s tail
Soy de España.I’m from Spain.
I’m from Spain.
agua de manantial ― springwater
una mesa de maderaa wooden table
a wooden table
Synonyms: sobre, acerca de
Están hablando del pasado.They're talking about the past.
They're talking about the past.
tratarse de ― to be about; to concern
Murió de hambre.He died of hunger.
He died of hunger.
un hombre de fea man of faith
a man of faith
Synonym: desde
el vuelo de Miami a Chicagothe flight from Miami to Chicago
the flight from Miami to Chicago
harto de ― sick of; tired of
Nos protege del frío.It protects us from the cold.
It protects us from the cold.
más de ― more than
menos de ― less than, fewer than
campamento de veranosummer camp
summer camp
De haberlo sabido, no lo habría dicho.If I had known, I wouldn't have said it.
If I had known, I wouldn't have said it.
de día ― during the daytime
de niño ― as a child; during childhood
Synonym: para
goma de mascar ― chewing gum
caña de pescar ― fishing rod

defs.etymology: From Latin quid (“what”), but usurping all the roles of Latin quod. Cognate with English who.

text: indicating desire or permission (used with the subjunctive)
examples: Él dice que está triste.He says that he/she is sad.
He says that he/she is sad.
Llego más tarde que tú.I am arriving later than you.
I am arriving later than you.
¡Ve más lento, que es resbaloso!Slow down,  it is slippery!
Slow down,  it is slippery!
Que te vaya  biengood luck to you.
good luck to you.
Que Dios me perdonemay God forgive me.
may God forgive me.
la estrella que está en la películathe star who is in the movie
the star who is in the movie
Synonym:  q
la mujer con la que yo habléthe woman with whom I spoke
the woman with whom I spoke
la casa que yo quierothe house that I want
the house that I want

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish non, from Latin nōn (compare Catalan no, Galician non, French non, Italian no, Portuguese não, Romanian nu).

text: eh? (used as a tag question, to emphasise what goes before or to request that the listener express an opinion about what has been said)

defs.etymology: Contracted form of Latin numero, ablative singular of numerus (“number”).

text: The first letter of the Spanish alphabet, written in the Latin script.

defs.etymology: From Latin ad (“to”)

text: Used before words referring to people, pets, or personified objects or places that function as direct objects: personal a.
examples:
Tenía en su casa una ama que pasaba de los cuarenta y una sobrina que no llegaba a los veinte, y un mozo de campo y plaza que así ensillaba el rocín como tomaba la podadera.
He had in his house a housekeeper past forty, a niece under twenty, and a lad for the field and market-place, who used to saddle the hack as well as handle the billhook.
He had in his house a housekeeper past forty, a niece under twenty, and a lad for the field and market-place, who used to saddle the hack as well as handle the billhook.
Lo busca a usted. He is looking for you.
He is looking for you.

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish ela, from Latin illa(m), feminine singular of ille.

text: la f sg (plural las, masculine el, masculine plural los)
accusative of ella, ello (when the antecedent's implied gender is feminine), and usted (when referring to a woman); her, it, you (formal)
impersonal neuter pronoun (accusative) in certain colloquial phrases: it, this
examples: La sabe toda.He/she knows everything
He/she knows everything
¡Dónde la viste!Where have you seen this!
Where have you seen this!
No te la creo.I don't believe you.
I don't believe you.

defs.etymology: From Latin ille.

text: el (plural los, feminine la, feminine plural las, neuter lo)

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish ela, from Latin illa.

text: Feminine singular definite article used before nouns which start with a stressed /a/:
examples: el alma, las almas ― the soul, the souls
el hacha, las hachas ― the axe, the axes

text: The twenty-sixth letter of the Spanish alphabet, called ye or i griega and written in the Latin script.

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish è or e, from Latin et.

text: (informal) what about, how about, where is/are the
examples: Es, pues, de saber que este sobredicho hidalgo, los ratos que estaba ocioso —que eran los más del año—, se daba a leer libros de caballerías, con tanta afición y gusto, que olvidó casi de todo punto el ejercicio de la caza y aun la administración de su hacienda; y llegó a tanto su curiosidad y desatino en esto, que vendió muchas hanegas de tierra de sembradura para comprar libros de caballerías en que leer, y, así, llevó a su casa todos cuantos pudo haber dellos.You must know, then, that the above-named gentleman whenever he was at leisure  gave himself up to reading books of chivalry with such ardour and avidity that he almost entirely neglected the pursuit of his field-sports, and even the management of his property; and to such a pitch did his eagerness and infatuation go that he sold many an acre of tillageland to buy books of chivalry to read, and brought home as many of them as he could get.

You must know, then, that the above-named gentleman whenever he was at leisure  gave himself up to reading books of chivalry with such ardour and avidity that he almost entirely neglected the pursuit of his field-sports, and even the management of his property; and to such a pitch did his eagerness and infatuation go that he sold many an acre of tillageland to buy books of chivalry to read, and brought home as many of them as he could get.
setenta y seis ― seventy-six
uno y uno son dos ― one plus one is two
¡Y por supuesto! ― Well, of course!
Pero, ¿y el concierto? ¿Ya no vamos? ― But what about the concert? Are we not going anymore?
¿Y la niña? ¿Está a salvo? ― How about the girl? Is she safe?
¿Y los archivos? Debo echarles un vistazo. ― Where are the files? I should take a look at them.

defs.etymology: From Latin est, from Proto-Italic *est, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁ésti. Cognate with Sanskrit अस्ति (ásti), English is.

text: Formal  second-person singular   (usted)  present indicative  form of ser.
Third-person singular   (él, ella, also used with usted?)  present indicative  form of ser; (he/she/it/one) is

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish en, from Latin in, from Proto-Italic *en, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁én (“in”). Cognate with Old English in and English in.

text: used after some verbs and translated by various prepositions in English
examples: Estoy en casa. ― I'm at home.
Estoy sentado en la computadora. ― I'm sitting at the computer.
en esta página ― on this page
en la caja en la mesa ― in the box on the table
en la antigüedad ― in antiquity
No conozco esta palabra en francés. I don't know this word in French.
I don't know this word in French.
en todos los idiomas ― in all languages
Pienso en tí. ― I'm thinking of you.
en el sentido ― in the sense
en nuestro afán ― in our eagerness

defs.etymology: From a Vulgar Latin lo, *illu. Masculine pronoun from Latin illum, singular masculine accusative of ille. Neuter article and pronoun form from Latin illud, neuter of ille. Compare Portuguese o.

text: neuter definite article used to make abstract nouns from adjectives; the
examples: lo pobre ― the poorness / what is poor / the poor thing

text: accusative of él, ello, and usted (when referring to a man); him, it, you (formal)
impersonal neuter pronoun (clitic form of ello); it, that
examples: lo veo ― I see it
lo es ― That’s it

defs.etymology: From uno, from Latin ūnus (“one”), from Old Latin oinos, from Proto-Italic *oinos, from Proto-Indo-European *óynos (“one”).

text: (before the noun) Apocopic form of uno one
un m (indefinite, plural unos, feminine una, feminine plural unas)

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish por, from Vulgar Latin *por, from Latin prō and per. Doublet of pro.

text: by (indicates the creator of a work)
for (indicates something given in an exchange)
due to, because of, for, for the sake of, out of (to express cause or motive)
according to, for, regarding (to express opinion or something concerning someone)
via, through, by (indicating the means of something)
for, for the sake of, on behalf of (indicating doing something for someone's benefit)
to (indicating something that has not yet passed)
about to (indicating something that will soon happen)
compared to; against; versus (indicating a comparison)
examples: La novela Cien años de Soledad fue escrita por Gabriel García Márquez.The novel One Hundred Years of Solitude was written by Gabriel García Márquez.
The novel One Hundred Years of Solitude was written by Gabriel García Márquez.
Lo compré por cincuenta euros.I bought this for fifty euros.
I bought this for fifty euros.
La mujer ve la puesta de sol por la ventana.The woman watches the sunset through the window.
The woman watches the sunset through the window.
Supongo que nuestra huésped se fue  por la puerta trasera porque no la he visto.I guess our guest went out the back door because I haven't seen her.
I guess our guest went out the back door because I haven't seen her.
El hombre camina por la calle. ― The man walks across the street.
Él no pudo venir por eso. ― He couldn't come due to that.
Por amor a su esposo, ella aguanta a sus suegros.Out of love for her husband, she puts up with his in-laws.
Out of love for her husband, she puts up with his in-laws.
por allí ― over there
ocho por siete ― eights times seven; eights by seven
Por mí, está bien. ― For all I care, it's fine.
¡Bien por ti! ― Good for you!
Por favor, devuelva este documento completado por correo electrónico.Please, return this document completed via email.
Please, return this document completed via email.
Mi profesor se salió por la tangente por una hora entera.My professor went off on a tangent for a whole hour.
My professor went off on a tangent for a whole hour.
No lo hago por ti. ― I'm not doing it for your sake.
Ella irá a trabajar por mí mañana.She will be filling in for me at work tomorrow.
She will be filling in for me at work tomorrow.
Cuesta diez dólares por artículo. ― It costs ten dollars per item.
Eso está por ver. ― That remains to be seen.
La hora aún está por confirmar. ― The time is yet to be confirmed.
Su hermana está por llegar del aeropuerto en cualquier momento.Her sister is about to arrive from the airport any minute now.
Her sister is about to arrive from the airport any minute now.
seis errores en los dos primeros parciales. Seis. 14 al final, por los 52 del rival.six errors in the first two sets. Six. 14 at the end, compared to his rival's 52.
six errors in the first two sets. Six. 14 at the end, compared to his rival's 52.

defs.etymology: From Latin quid.

examples: ¿Qué camisa quiere? ― Which shirt do you want?
No sabía qué hacer ― I didn't know what to do

text: (before a noun) what a; such (used as an intensifier)
(before an adjective) how (used as a modifier to indicate surprise, delight, or other strong feelings)
examples: ¡Qué lástima! ― What a pity!
¡Qué suerte! ― What luck!
¡Qué casa más bonita! ― What a pretty house!
¡Qué mierda de tiempo! ― What shitty weather!
¡Qué feo! ― How ugly!
¡Qué alto! ― He's/it's so tall!
¡Qué guay! ― That's so cool!
¿Qué ves? ― What do you see?

defs.etymology: From Latin mē (accusative singular of ego), from Proto-Indo-European *(h₁)me-. As an indirect object, possibly in part from Latin mihi (dative of ego), through a Vulgar Latin *mi.

text: (personal, dative pronoun) dative of yo: to me, for me

defs.etymology: From Latin ūna, feminine of ūnus.

examples: a la una, a las dos y a las tresafter three...one, two, three
after three...one, two, three

text: one (an indefinite plural pronoun using a singular feminine item, used for females)

defs.etymology: See the etymology of the corresponding lemma form.

text: Formal second-person singular (usted) imperative form of unir.
First-person singular   (yo)  present subjunctive  form of unir.
Formal  second-person singular   (usted)  present subjunctive  form of unir.
Third-person singular   (él, ella, also used with usted?)  present subjunctive  form of unir.

defs.etymology: From Latin illōs accusative plural masculine of ille.

examples: ¿Qué hacen los muchachos? ― What do the boys do?

text: accusative of ellos and ustedes (when referring to more than one man); them, you all (formal)
examples: los que no hablanthose who do not speak
those who do not speak

defs.etymology: From Latin sē.

text: se m or f (third person, including ‘usted’ and ‘ustedes’)
Third person (also used for usted and ustedes) reflexive direct or indirect object oneself, himself, herself, itself, yourself; each other; one another
Used to convey the meaning of the English passive voice in the third person and with usted and ustedes
examples: ¿Cómo se llama? ― What is your name?
Se dice que... ― It is said that...
Aquí se habla español ― Spanish is spoken here / They speak Spanish here.

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish ge (from Latin illī, compare Portuguese lhe, Italian gli), whose pronunciation shifted from /ʒe/ to /ʃe/ in Early Modern Spanish, at which point it was reanalyzed as /se/ (rather than shifting to /xe/ as expected).

text: se m or f (third person, including ‘usted’ and ‘ustedes’)
Used instead of indirect object pronouns le and les before the direct object pronouns lo, la, los, or las.
examples: El samaritano se las dio. ― The Samaritan gave them to him.

text: The name of the Latin-script letter T.

defs.etymology: From Latin tē (accusative of tū), from Proto-Indo-European *twé, *te, accusative of *túh₂ (“you”).

text: dative of tú: to you, for you
examples: Te voy a hacer tus calzones...."La Cucaracha"I’m going to make your britches
I’m going to make your britches

defs.etymology: From Latin cum (“with”), from Proto-Italic *kom, from Proto-Indo-European *ḱóm (“next to, at, with, along”).

examples: Antonym: sin
Yo cuento con ustedes. ― I count on you.

defs.etymology: A corruption of the older form pora (a combination of por and a, or from Latin pro ad), influenced by the archaic preposition par.[2]

text: to, in order to, so, for (expressing the intended purpose of an action)
by, due, due on, due by (expressing a deadline)
for (expressing contrast from what is expected)
for, to, in one's opinion, as far as one is concerned (expressing an opinion, perception or perspective)
for (expressing using one's efforts for a group or an authority figure such as a sports team or a company/boss)
examples: La niña compró un regalo de navidad para su abuela. ― The girl bought a Christmas gift for her grandmother.
Ahora me gustaría hacer un truco de magia para ustedes. ― I'd now like to perform a magic trick for you-all.
Synonyms: pa',  pa
Estudio cada noche sin descanso para conseguir un trabajo decente al fin de todo esto.I study every night tirelessly so I get a decent job at the end of all this.
I study every night tirelessly so I get a decent job at the end of all this.
Voy a salir temprano para evitar el tráfico. ― I am going to leave early to avoid traffic.
Necesito tu decisión para fin de mes. ― I need your decision by the end of the month.
Sus proyectos de grupo son para el viernes sin excepción. ― Your group projects are due Friday without exception.
Para un turista americano, él es en realidad bastante respetuoso.For an American tourist, he is actually pretty respectful.
For an American tourist, he is actually pretty respectful.
Para mí, la música es lo único bueno sobre esa película.For me, the music was the only good thing about that film.
For me, the music was the only good thing about that film.
Para mi hermano, su esposa tiene toda la razón.As far as my brother is concerned, his wife is totally in the right.
As far as my brother is concerned, his wife is totally in the right.
Mi sobrino juega para el equipo de los Patos Poderosos. ― My nephew plays for the Mighty Ducks' team.
Trabajamos para la misma jefe aunque no al mismo tiempo.We worked for the same boss but not at the same time.
We worked for the same boss but not at the same time.
Ella trabajó para Microsoft durante años, pero ahora trabaja para Apple.She worked for Microsoft for years, but now she works for Apple.
She worked for Microsoft for years, but now she works for Apple.

defs.etymology: Form of parar.

defs.etymology: From Latin meus, when it was eliding before a vowel-initial word in speech.

text: mi sg (first-person singular possessive singular, plural mis)
(before the noun) Apocopic form of mío, my

words: mu; the Greek letter Μ, μ

text: mu; the Greek letter Μ, μ
examples: Synonym: mu

defs.etymology: From Latin per hoc (“by this”). Compare Italian però, Old Franco-Provençal enperoi.

text: well well; so; well (used for emphasis)
examples: Mi casa es pequeña pero cómoda.My house is small but comfortable.
My house is small but comfortable.
Synonym: mas

defs.etymology: From Latin sīc (est).

examples: Ganaron los síes.The ayes have it.
The ayes have it.

defs.etymology: From Latin sibi, from Proto-Indo-European *sébʰye, dative of *swé (“self”). Cognate with French soi, Italian sé, and Portuguese si.

text: himself, herself, itself, themselves, yourself, yourselves (form of se used after prepositions)
examples: para sí ― for himself/herself/itself/themselves/yourself/yourselves

defs.etymology: From Latin si (“if”).
From Old Spanish, from Latin bene (“well”).

text: well, fine, okay (state of being satisfied with the status quo)
examples: Toca bien el piano. ― He plays the piano well.
Antonym: mal
hasta aquí todo bien ― so far so good
Bien podrías acabar con ello temprano. ― You might as well get it over with early.
Amanda y Carlos vienen de una familia bien.Amanda and Carlos come from a well-to-do family.
Amanda and Carlos come from a well-to-do family.
Las colonias bienes están en las afueras de la ciudad.The upscale neighborhoods are in the city suburbs.
The upscale neighborhoods are in the city suburbs.

text: (plural) goods, property, possessions, assets, wealth, estate
examples: Es por el bien de toda la comunidad. ― It's for the good of the whole community.
Antonym: mal
para bien o para mal ― for better or for worse
He vuelto para bien esta vez. ― I'm back for good this time.

defs.etymology: From Latin ipsum, neuter of ipse.
From Latin suus, suum, from Proto-Italic *sowos, from Proto-Indo-European *sewos, from *swé.

text: su (third person possessive of singular, plural sus)
(before the noun) Apocopic form of suyo His, her, its, one's, their, your (formal)
(before the noun, formal) Apocopic form of suyo Your

words: “su”, in Diccionario de la lengua española, Vigésima tercera edición, Real Academia Española, 2014

examples: Vino con su amigo.He came with his friend.
He came with his friend.
Habló a sus hijas.He spoke to his daughters.
He spoke to his daughters.
Pesa sus dos kilogramos.It weighs about two kilograms.
It weighs about two kilograms.

defs.etymology: From Latin illās, accusative feminine plural of ille.

text: accusative of ellas and ustedes (when referring to more than one woman); them, you all (formal)
examples: las que no hablanthose  who do not speak.
those  who do not speak.

defs.etymology: From Vulgar Latin *eo, attested from the 6th century in Romance, from Latin ego, from Proto-Italic *egō; akin to Greek εγώ (egó), Sanskrit अहम् (aham), all from Proto-Indo-European *éǵh₂. Akin to Italian io, Sicilian iu, Catalan jo, Aragonese and Asturian yo.

text: First-person singular pronoun in the nominative case; I

defs.etymology: prep de + article el. Akin to Portuguese do and French du.
From Old Spanish commo, from Latin cōmō̆, a non-literary form of quōmodo (“how”). Cognate with Catalan com, Italian come and French comme.

text: as (to such an extent or degree)
examples: No es tan alta como nosotras.She's not as tall as us.
She's not as tall as us.
Hemos esperado como media hora.We've waited like half an hour.
We've waited like half an hour.

text: as (introducing a basis of comparison or equality)
(followed by the subjunctive) if, unless (under the condition that)
examples: ¿Tienes tanta hambre como yo?Are you as hungry as I am?
Are you as hungry as I am?
Como nunca vio mi mensaje, vamos sin ella.Since she never saw my message, we're going without her.
Since she never saw my message, we're going without her.
Synonym: ya que
Me gusta como hablas.I like the way you talk.
I like the way you talk.
Como llegues tarde otra vez, ¡te mato!If you arrive late again, I'll kill you!
If you arrive late again, I'll kill you!
Synonym: si

text: as (in the manner or role specified)
examples: Mis ahijados me ven como un tío.My godchildren see me as an uncle.
My godchildren see me as an uncle.
Algunos países de Asia, como Laos y Vietnam...Some countries in Asia, such as Laos and Vietnam...
Some countries in Asia, such as Laos and Vietnam...
Synonyms: por ejemplo, como por ejemplo
Llevan gafas redondas como las de John Lennon.They wear round glasses like John Lennon's.
They wear round glasses like John Lennon's.

defs.etymology: See the etymology of the corresponding lemma form.

text: First-person singular   (yo)  present indicative  form of comer.

defs.etymology: From Vulgar Latin *accum hīc, from Latin eccum + hīc (“this here”), the latter from hīc, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ǵʰi-ḱe (“this, here”).

examples: Synonym:  acá
Antonyms: ahí, allá, allí

defs.etymology: From Latin tuus, from Proto-Indo-European *towos.

text: tu sg (second person singular possessive of singular, of plural tus)
(before the noun) Apocopic form of tuyo, your
examples: Synonym:  su

defs.etymology: From Latin magis, whence also English master.

text: (with definite article) most; -est (used to make superlatives)
used with qué to express emphasis
examples: Una olla de algo más vaca que carnero, salpicón las más noches, duelos y quebrantos los sábados, lantejas los viernes, algún palomino de añadidura los domingos, consumían las tres partes de su haciendaA pot of stew of rather more beef than mutton, a salad on most nights, scraps on Saturdays, lentils on Fridays, and a pigeon or so extra on Sundays, made away with three-quarters of his income.
A pot of stew of rather more beef than mutton, a salad on most nights, scraps on Saturdays, lentils on Fridays, and a pigeon or so extra on Sundays, made away with three-quarters of his income.
Teresa es más lista que su hermano.Teresa is more clever than her brother.
Teresa is more clever than her brother.
Hay más de cien personas aquí.There are more than a hundred people here.
There are more than a hundred people here.
Teresa es la más inteligente de la clase.Teresa is the most intelligent in her class.
Teresa is the most intelligent in her class.
la cosa más grandethe biggest thing
the biggest thing
algo mássomething/anything else
something/anything else
nadie másnobody else
nobody else
¡Qué paisaje más hermoso!What a pretty landscape!
What a pretty landscape!
¡Qué niño más tonto!What a silly boy!
What a silly boy!
uno más uno es igual a dosone plus one is equal to two
one plus one is equal to two

defs.etymology: From Latin illī, dative of ille.

text: to him, for him; dative of él
to her, for her; dative of ella
to it, for it; dative of ello
to you, for you (formal); dative of usted
(gender-neutral, neologism) to them, for them (singular); dative of elle
examples: Mi mamá va a escribirle una carta. ― My mom is going to write him a letter.
Le dio un beso a Ana. ― He gave Ana a kiss.
¡Ponle esfuerzo! ― Put some effort into it!
¿A usted le gustan los caballos? ― Do you like horses?
Le diré que te llame. ― I will tell them to call you.

defs.etymology: From Latin istud, from iste.

examples: ¿Qué es esto? ― What is this?

defs.etymology: Inherited from Latin tōtus. Compare Catalan tot, French tout. Related to total, which was borrowed from Latin.

text: todo m (plural todos, feminine toda, feminine plural todas)
examples: Antonym: ningún
todos los días ― every day
Todos somos jóvenes. ― We are all young.
todo tipo de ― every type/kind/sort of; all kinds/sorts of
Synonym:  cada
Toda persona es un individuo. ― Every person is an individual.
Antonym: nada
todo lo que dijiste ― everything that you said

defs.etymology: From Latin iam. Compare Portuguese já, French déjà and Italian già.

text: (emphatic) emphatic (similar to the use of English "so" or "oh" as an interjection)
examples: Púlsalo ya. ― Press it now.
Preparados, listos, ya. ― Ready, set, go.
Synonyms: ahora,  ahorita
Ya lo hice. ― I already did it.
Synonym: ahora mismo
¡Ya lo sé! ― I know!
no ya... ― not only...
ya, pero... ― yes, but...
ya que... ― now that...

text: first (something) then (something else); first (something), now (something else)
examples: ¡Ya lluvia ya nieve!First rain, now snow!
First rain, now snow!
ya sol ya lluviawhether sun or rain
whether sun or rain

text: (colloquial) Used to acknowledge or dismiss the previous statement.
examples: Synonyms: vamos, vámonos, adelante, ándale,  órale,  ya po
—Sabes que quedamos con Antonio esta tarde. —Ya."You know we're hanging out with Antonio tonight." "I know."
"You know we're hanging out with Antonio tonight." "I know."
—No podrás venir, que trabajas ese día. —Ya, pero cerramos temprano los viernes."You can't come, you're working that day." "Right, but we close early on Fridays."
"You can't come, you're working that day." "Right, but we close early on Fridays."

text: First-person singular   (yo)  present indicative  form of estar; am.

defs.etymology:
From Old Spanish agora, from Latin hāc hōrā (“at this time”).
According to Coromines and Pascual, the original form agora was, from the early modern period, increasingly left to both high and low registers, in favour of the phonetically reduced ahora. Francisco de Quevedo in the early 17th century mocks agora in his Cuento de Cuentos as a "rustic vulgarity", although the term continued to be used by archaizing poets into the 19th century, and it continues to survive to this day in various non-prestigious dialects. As for ahora, there is a very rare early attestation (spelled aora) in Juan Ruiz in the early 14th century, but the term doesn't enter common written usage until the 16th century with writers like Cervantes and Góngora, side-by-side the older agora. Compare Portuguese agora.

text: just now, just a moment ago (in the past)
very soon, in a moment (in the future)
(usually preceded by de) of nowadays, of today, latter-day
examples: Synonyms:  ahorita, ya
Synonyms: hace un momento,  ahorita
Synonyms:  ahorita, ya
La juventud de ahora entiende esto y más. ― Today's youth understands this and more.
Synonym: hoy
Ahora me levanté temprano y con ánimo. ― Today I woke up early and full of energy.
Te veré ahora en la noche. ― I'll see you later today in the evening.
Synonyms: hoy, hoy en día
Te quiero mucho. Ahora eso no quiere decir que haré lo que digas.I love you. However, that doesn't mean I'll do what you say.
I love you. However, that doesn't mean I'll do what you say.
Synonym: sin embargo
Ahora dice una cosa, ahora dice lo contrario.She sometimes says one thing, and then other times she says the opposite.
She sometimes says one thing, and then other times she says the opposite.
Ahora en la sala, ahora en el comedor, había un desastre por doquier.Whether you looked at the kitchen, or the dining room, there was a disaster everywhere.
Whether you looked at the kitchen, or the dining room, there was a disaster everywhere.
Synonym: ora ... ora ...

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish muito, from Latin multus (“much, many”).

examples: Synonym: re-
Tengo un coche muy caro.I have a very expensive car.
I have a very expensive car.

Third-person singular   (él, ella, also used with usted?)  present indicative  form of haber.

defs.etymology: From Latin ista, feminine of iste.
From Old Spanish así, from Vulgar Latin *ad sīc. Closely parallel to Aromanian ashi, Portuguese assim, Romanian așa. Compare also Catalan així, French ainsi, Italian così.

text: like this; like that; as such; thus; so; thereby; this way, that way
(followed by a subjunctive clause) Used to express wishes of misfortune against someone, or to cast a spell
examples: ¡Así se hace! Lo hiciste genial. ― Way to go! You did great.
Así es la vida. ― Such is life.
Si no paras de hablar así, vas a hacerme llorar.If you don't stop talking like that, you're going to make me cry.
If you don't stop talking like that, you're going to make me cry.
¡Así reciba un dolor de cabeza!I hope he gets a headache!
I hope he gets a headache!

defs.etymology: See the etymology of the corresponding lemma form.

defs.etymology: From Latin alĭquod.

examples: Synonym: alguna cosa

Me parece algo extraño.It seems rather strange to me.
It seems rather strange to me.

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish ha ý (“it has there”) (compare Catalan hi ha and French il y a), from ha, third-person singular present of aver (“to have”), + ý, from Latin ibī (“there”).

text: (impersonal) Present indicative  form of haber, there is, there are
examples: Hay dos tiendas que venden películas.There are two stores that sell films.
There are two stores that sell films.

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish, inherited from Latin bonus (“good”), from Old Latin duenos, later duonus, from Proto-Italic *dwenos, from Proto-Indo-European *dew- (“to show favor, revere”). Doublet of bonus, a later borrowing.

text: bueno (feminine buena, masculine plural buenos, feminine plural buenas, comparative mejor, superlative buenísimo or bonísimo or óptimo)
examples: Antonym: malo
Que tengas una buena noche. ― Have a good night.
Que tengas un buen viaje. ― Have a good trip.

text: (used at the start of a phrase) well; a short pause in a sentence
(interrogatively, Mexico) Expression used when answering the phone, often with the pronunciation /bweˈno/, rather than /ˈbweno/.
examples: Synonyms: vale, de acuerdo, está bien
Bueno, pues, mira. ― Well, then, look.
¿Bueno? ― Hello?
Synonyms: aló, diga, dígame, sí

defs.etymology: From Latin ille (“that one”).

text: él (masculine third-person singular pronoun, feminine ella, neuter ello, masculine plural ellos, feminine plural ellas)
he, him, masculine personal third person subject and disjunctive pronoun (used as a subject and after prepositions)
it, masculine non-personal third-person subject and disjunctive pronoun (used as a subject and after prepositions to refer to masculine nouns)
examples: Él es mi hermano. ― He is my brother.
Lo hice para él. ― I did it for him.
¿Es esto un libro? - Sí, él es. ― Is this a book? - Yes, it is.
¡Mi coche! ¿Qué le pasó a él? ― My car! What happened to it?

defs.etymology: From Latin quandō. Compare English cue.

examples: Ven cuando estés listo.Come when you're ready.

From Latin tū, from Proto-Italic *tū, from Proto-Indo-European *túh₂ (whence English thou).

examples: Synonym:  vos

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish nos, from accusative Latin nōs and dative Latin nōbīs, from Proto-Italic *nōs.

text: dative of nosotros: to us, for us
(reflexive) reflexive of nosotros: ourselves; each other
(archaic, formal) first person; I (singular, cf. vos)
examples: A eso de las cuatro de la mañana todos nos dijimos buenas noches.Around four in the morning, we all told each other good night.
Around four in the morning, we all told each other good night.

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish nada, inherited from Latin (nūlla rēs) nāta (literally “no born thing, not a thing born”), an extension of nēmō nātus (“not a soul”, literally “nobody born”). For descendants of the other part of the expression see Galician ren (“nothing”), French rien (“nothing”), Catalan res (“nothing; anything”). For the grammaticalization of an original nominal as a negative see Jespersen's Cycle and French personne, pas; see also nadie, from the same root.

examples: No hay nada en la mesa. ― There is nothing on the table.
Nada ocurrió ayer. ― Nothing happened yesterday.
No veo nada. ― I don’t see anything.
Me niego a creer nada de lo que dice. ― I refuse to believe anything he says.
Synonym: ninguna cosa
Sin ti, soy una nada. ― Without you, I am no thing at all.
Ya no me siento una nada. ― I don't feel like I am nothing at all anymore.
Salió de la nada. ― It came out of nowhere, out of the void.

defs.etymology: See the etymology of the corresponding lemma form.

defs.etymology: From Latin cōmō̆, a non-literary form of quōmodo.

text: (interrogative) sorry? what? (expressing surprise or asking to repeat)

examples: Stefan Zweig y Agatha Christie, Poe y Alfonso Reyes, Flaubert y Leopardi, Shakespeare y Valle-Inclán son los pasajeros de Aquí viven leones , embriagadora ruta por las luces, las sombras, las manías, los dóndes, los cómos y los porqués –el contexto, en suma- que rodean a los grandes escritores y a la génesis de sus grandes obras.

defs.etymology:
From Old Spanish seer, from two sources by suppletion:
Latin sedeō, sedēre (“to sit, to reside”), from Proto-Italic *sedēō, from Proto-Indo-European *sed-. The infinitive, gerund, imperative, past participle, and present subjunctive come from this verb.
Latin sum, from Proto-Italic *ezom, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁ésti. The forms that derived from here are the present tenses, the imperfect, the imperfect and future subjunctives, and the preterite tenses (although the preterite tense, future subjunctive, and imperfect subjunctive come from a different root, Proto-Indo-European *bʰuH-).

text: ser (first-person singular present soy, first-person singular preterite fui, past participle sido)
to be (in the passive voice sense)
examples: ¿Qué voy a ser si te he dado lo que soy?What am I going to be if I've given you what I am?
What am I going to be if I've given you what I am?
Si fueras una gota de agua, nadie volvería a tener sedIf you were a drop of water, no one would thirst again
If you were a drop of water, no one would thirst again
Yo soy de los Estados Unidos. ― I am from the United States.
Errar es humano. ― To err is human.
La guitarra fue tocada. ― The guitar was played.
La fiesta será mañana. ― The party will be tomorrow.

text: First-person singular   (yo)  present indicative  form of querer.

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish fazer, from Latin faciō, facere (“to do, to make”), from Proto-Italic *fakjō, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁- (“to put, place, set”). The first-person indicative and present subjunctive may have been influenced by Latin agō, but more likely present voicing of the Latin -c- between vowels, after dropping the -i-.

text: hacer (first-person singular present hago, first-person singular preterite hice, past participle hecho)
(transitive) to make (eg. someone do something or feel a certain way.)
(transitive, intransitive, optionally with de) to play (a part in a play)
(reflexive, transitive, intransitive) to become; to get
(reflexive, transitive, intransitive) to pretend being, play
(reflexive, transitive) to prep, adorn, do (a body part)
(reflexive, intransitive with a) to get used to (chiefly in idioms)
(intransitive) to arrive (said of a certain time), be now
examples: ¿Qué haces? ― What are you doing?
No sé que hago. ― I don't know what I'm doing.
Prefiero no hacerlo ― I prefer not to do it.
Empecemos a hacer el pastel. ― Let's start making the cake.
Le gustaba hacer poemas placenteros. ― She liked to make pleasant poems.
No sabe cómo hacerla feliz.He doesn't know how to make her happy.
He doesn't know how to make her happy.
Lo hiciste llorar ~ Hiciste que llorara.You made him cry.
You made him cry.
hace frío ― it's cold
hace calor ― it's hot
hace sol ― it's sunny
hace viento ― it's windy
Synonym: estar
hacer pis, pipí, el número uno ― to pee
hacer caca, pupú, el número dos ― to poo
hacer la princesa ― to play the princess
hacer de princesa ― to play a princess
hacer de Óscar ― to play  Oscar
¡Hazte vegetariano! ― Become vegetarian!
Me haré rico. ― I will get rich.
Ese niño se hizo todo un hombre. ― That boy became a real man.
Synonym: volverse
hacerse el tonto ― to pretend being a fool, play the fool
hacerse la víctima ― to play the victim
Háganse los sofisticados si quieren, igual nadie les cree. ― You can pretend to be sophisticated if you want, no one believes you anyway.
No te hagás: vos sabés lo que hiciste. ― Don't play the fool, you know what you did.
hacerse las uñas ― to do one's nails
El cuerpo se hace a las fatigas. ― The body gets used to tiredness.
El caballo se hace al fuego. ― A horse gets used to fire .
Se hace tarde. ― It's getting late.
Se hicieron las doce. ― It was now/suddenly 12 o'clock.
Nos quedan muchos haceres. ― We have a lot of tasks left.
Synonyms: quehacer, acción

From Latin sonus, probably through the intermediate of Old Occitan son (or influenced by it); alternatively, but less likely, regressively derived from the verb sonar (the more expected form is sueno that appeared in some Medieval texts). Compare English sound and Portuguese som.

defs.etymology: From vuestra merced (lit. "your mercy" (etymological) or "your grace" (idiomatic)), an honorific style. In 17th-century Spanish, there were a number of variants, including the intermediate forms vuesasted and vusted. Cf. Portuguese você, Galician vostede and Catalan vostè. The following list has the variants reported by Coromines and Pascual, with their reported first year of attestation:

text: (Costa Rica, Colombia, chiefly Bogotá) second person informal; you (singular)

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish entonce, from Latin in + *tunce, the latter an archaic form of tunc (“then”). Compare Portuguese então and Romanian atunci.

text: then, next, thereupon, at that time, at that point
examples: Desde entonces, siempre he tenido cuidado.Since then I've always been careful.
Since then I've always been careful.
Entonces, el ladrón se fue.After that, the thief left.
After that, the thief left.
Estaba lloviendo antes, entonces debes traer un paraguas.It was raining before, so you should bring an umbrella.
It was raining before, so you should bring an umbrella.

defs.etymology: Probably from French holà (“hey! stop!”).  This is related to greetings in Germanic cognates such as Dutch hola, Old High German holā, emphatic imperative of Old High German holōn (“to fetch, used especially in hailing a ferryman”)The Diccionario de la lengua española compares the Germanic expressions English hello and German hallo.  Also compared is Arabic وَٱللّٰه‎ (wal-lāh, “really?, by God!”), but support for this is lacking.
From Latin sōlus (“alone, sole, only”).

text: solo (feminine sola, masculine plural solos, feminine plural solas)

defs.etymology: From Latin sōlum.

examples: Synonyms: solamente, únicamente
Solo quiero salir. ― I just want to leave.
No solo... sino también... ― Not only... but also...
La máquina se lava sola.The machine washes itself.; The machine is self-washing.
The machine washes itself.; The machine is self-washing.

defs.etymology: Inherited from Latin vēritātem, from vērus (“true, genuine”). Compare Catalan veritat, French vérité, Italian verità, Portuguese verdade.

defs.etymology: From tanto, from Latin tam.

examples: Eres tan rico como te sientes. ― You are as rich as you feel.
¡Ese tipo es tan patán! ― That guy is such a jerk!

defs.etymology: From Latin quem, accusative of quī.

text: (followed by a subjunctive clause in the imperfect or pluperfect tense) if only; I wish
examples: ¿Con quién hablo? ― With whom am I speaking?
¡Quién lo hubiera creído! ― Who would have believed it!?
¿De quién es este libro? ― Whose book is this?
¿Quién enseña la clase? ― Who teaches the class?
¿Quién carajo es Kevin? ― Who the hell is Kevin?
no sabe quién ha llamadoHe doesn't know who has called
He doesn't know who has called
¡Quién tuviera 20 años! ― How I wish I was 20 [years old]!
¡Quién hubiera tocado la lotería! ― If only I'd won the lottery!

text: plural of su; one's, his, her, its, their (with plural possessee)

defs.etymology: From Old Spanish, from Latin tempus, from Proto-Indo-European *tempos (“stretch”), from the root *temp- (“to stretch, string”). Doublet of tempo.

text: a while, period of time, long time, length of time, indeterminate amount of time
examples: Amiga, ha pasado demasiado tiempo. ― Friend, it's been too long.
Hace tiempo que yo no tomaba un buen trago. ― It's been a while since I've had a good drink.
¿Qué tiempo hace? ― What is the weather like? / How is the weather?

defs.etymology: From Latin duōs, accusative of duo, from Proto-Italic *duō, from Proto-Indo-European *dwóh₁. Cognates include Ancient Greek δύο (dúo), Old English twa (English two), Persian دو‎.
From Latin ipsa, from ipse.
From Old Spanish nunqua, from Vulgar Latin *numqua, from Latin numquam, from ne + umquam.

examples: Nunca he probado la langosta.I've never tasted lobster.
I've never tasted lobster.
Nunca te va a hacer una chingadera.He will never screw you over.
He will never screw you over.
Synonyms: jamás, en su vida
Estamos mejor que nunca.We're better than ever.
We're better than ever.

defs.etymology: See donde.

examples: ¿Dónde está tu madre?Where is your mother?
Where is your mother?

defs.etymology: From Latin vādit, third person singular present active indicative of vādō.
